abstract.p: The foundational charters in the pure form, i.e. pivoting on an account somehow describing the foundation ritual, seem to be rare (at least among the mss of Ethio-SPaRe).

Most frequently such a document includes a formula concerning gwəlt which is given to the institution upon the foundation, but also a reference to the establishing of the institution, in whatever form.

In rare cases, the account about a foundation, originally of documentary nature, becomes a literary work of historiography, like the story of the foundation of Dabra Bǝrhan Sǝllāse in Gondar, by Iyasu I in several versions, or Dabra Ḍaḥay Qʷǝsqʷām by Iyasu II.

Sometimes we learn only indirectly that a document is related to the foundation of a church or it is called like this in a scholarly literature, but no relevant features can be solicited from the document itself, as it is the case with the recently published charters of Baʾātā church in Gondar (Kropp, “The Foundation of the Church Däbrä Tebäb Bä’ata Maryam”. Also the term gwəlt is not directly use there).
Records and accounts on the church foundation/ construction of church, of various types, without clear information on gwəlt, are rare.
